content: If there are no objections, I'd like to change the difficulty to Hard based on success rate. In fact Part 1 has a lower success rate, but of course it wouldn't make sense to categorize this as any easier than that.
If there are no objections, I'd like to add cover art to this puzzle.

Another thing (sorry for all the comments): I found the last validator more difficult than the last test.  It might be nice to switch them to avoid the frustration of having to change parameters and resubmit often.  (If you submit way too often, CodinGame starts to make you do CAPCHAs.)

I really liked both this puzzle and the previous one.  One comment was that this puzzle was pretty easy.  I plugged in what I thought were "the default parameters" into the neural network and only the last two gave me trouble.  I also don't know if you could provide an explanation of what more/less/different hidden layers do.  (More layers or nodes seems to help, but it also increases the computation time.  Maybe that is all there is too it.)
"testInputs" is used in the section "Input", and "testValues" is used in the section "Output". I wonder if they refer to the same thing?

- Changed the in / out format to better match Part 1

 - Changed from 16 x 16 in / out to 8 x 8

 - Added an XOR case to force a hidden layer
Good catch. They do refer to the same thing. I have fixed it.

Also, on the theme of this one being easy, do you think you could come up with a puzzle (not this one, but maybe a part 3 or 4) which uses a neural network but as part of a more interesting problem where it is not just binary in / binary out?  Maybe even one with a fun theme or story.  (On this puzzle, I never paid attention to what the actual problems I was solving were.)  I understand that this is easier said then done.
Thanks. I took your suggestion and flipped test and validator for the last one. I will get back to you on your other comments later.

As at this moment, 770 players have started solving Part 1, with a success rate of 24%; 355 players have started solving Part 2, with a success rate of 47%. My interpretation of why Part 2 has a higher success rate is that normally, only the players who have been able to solve Part 1 will move on to Part 2.
In that case success rate shouldn't be the guide in absolute terms, altho presumably it is actually more difficult than Part 1.

Ok, here is an idea.  (I have no idea if it will work.)  Have the user write a program to recognize and replicate cellular automata patterns.  I am thinking about patterns like Conway's Game of Life or simpler patterns, like the shift-left map, where the state of the cell at stage n+1 is a function of the state of the cell plus eight surrounding cells at stage n.  (Does the input size have to be a power of 2?  If so find patterns which only depend on the surrounding 8 cells.)  (Have cells outside of the grid count as a 0, or alternately have the grid wrap around like a torus--a la the Astroids game.)  Show the user a few frames of a small grid and have them use the neural network to predict the next grid frame.

I thought about this idea some more and implemented some of it.  It seems to work.  The neural network can successfully predict various automata rules.  One however needs to make sure it is interesting for a least some cases.  For many rules and initial configurations of the grid, a lookup table suffices.  There are only 2**9 = 512 inputs and many of the needed ones come up in the training data.  However with a complicated rule like the Game of Life, there are configurations that never come up in the training data (assuming I start with a random starting pattern), yet the network can still predict that, say, an empty cell surrounded by 4 live cells stays empty even if it hasn't seen that exact configuration before.  So I think it is a promising problem.  (It doesn't do as well on the game High Life, since it has trouble recognizing the outlier 6-neighbor case.)
